**Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,** popularly known as "[Santa's ninth
reindeer](/wiki/Santa_Claus%27s_reindeer "Santa Claus's reindeer")", is a
fabled reindeer created by [Robert Lewis May](/wiki/Robert_Lewis_May "Robert
Lewis May"). Rudolph is usually depicted as the lead reindeer pulling Santa's
sleigh on [Christmas Eve](/wiki/Christmas_Eve "Christmas Eve"), though he is a
young buck who has only adolescent antlers and a glowing red nose. Though he
receives scrutiny for it, the luminosity of his nose is so great that it
illuminates the team's path through harsh [winter
weather](/wiki/Winter_weather "Winter weather").

Rudolph first appeared in a 1939 booklet written by [Robert L.
May](/wiki/Robert_L._May "Robert L. May") and published by [Montgomery
Ward](/wiki/Montgomery_Ward "Montgomery Ward"), the department store.[1][2][3]

The story is owned by The Rudolph Company, LP and has been adapted in numerous
forms including [a popular song](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer_\(song\)
"Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer \(song\)"), [the iconic 1964 television
special](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer_\(TV_special\) "Rudolph the Red-
Nosed Reindeer \(TV special\)") and sequels, and [a feature
film](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer:_The_Movie "Rudolph the Red-Nosed
Reindeer: The Movie") and sequel. Character Arts, LLC manages the licensing
for the Rudolph Company, LP. In many countries, Rudolph has become a figure of
Christmas [folklore](/wiki/Folklore "Folklore"). 2014 marked the 75th
anniversary of the character[4] and the 50th anniversary of the television
special.[5] A series of postage stamps featuring Rudolph was issued by the
[United States Postal Service](/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United
States Postal Service") on November 6, 2014.[6][7]

## Publication history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Publication history")]

Robert L. May created Rudolph in 1939 as an assignment for
[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago")-based [Montgomery
Ward](/wiki/Montgomery_Ward "Montgomery Ward"). The retailer had been buying
and giving away [coloring books](/wiki/Coloring_book "Coloring book") for
Christmas every year and it was decided that creating their own book would
save money. May considered naming the reindeer "Rollo" or "Reginald" before
deciding upon using the name "Rudolph."[8] In its first year of publication,
Montgomery Ward distributed 2.4 million copies of Rudolph's story.[9] The
story is written as a poem in [anapestic
tetrameter](/wiki/Anapestic_tetrameter "Anapestic tetrameter"), the same meter
as "[A Visit from St. Nicholas](/wiki/A_Visit_from_St._Nicholas "A Visit from
St. Nicholas")" (also known as "'Twas the Night Before Christmas").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Publication and reprint rights for the book _Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer_
are controlled by [Pearson PLC](/wiki/Pearson_PLC "Pearson PLC").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

While May was pondering how best to craft a Christmas story about a reindeer,
while staring out his office window in downtown Chicago, a thick fog from
[Lake Michigan](/wiki/Lake_Michigan "Lake Michigan") blocked his view—giving
him a flash of inspiration. "Suddenly I had it!" he recalled. "A nose! A
bright red nose that would shine through fog like a spotlight."[10]

The cultural significance of a red nose has changed since the story's
publication. In 1930's popular culture, a bright red nose was closely
associated with chronic alcoholism and drunkards, so the story idea was
initially rejected. May asked his illustrator friend at Montgomery Ward,
Denver Gillen, to draw "cute reindeer", using zoo deer as models. The alert,
bouncy character Gillen developed convinced management to support the
idea.[11]

Maxton Books published the first mass-market edition of _Rudolph_ in
1947[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] and a sequel, _Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer Shines Again_ , in
1954.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] In 1992, Applewood Books published _Rudolph 's Second Christmas_,
an unpublished sequel that Robert May wrote in 1947.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
2003, [Penguin Books](/wiki/Penguin_Books "Penguin Books") issued a reprint
version of the original _Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer_ with new artwork by
Lisa Papp.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Penguin also reprinted May's sequels, _Rudolph
Shines Again_ and _Rudolph 's Second Christmas_ (now retitled _Rudolph to the
Rescue_).[12]

## The story[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: The story")]

The story chronicles the experiences of Rudolph, a youthful reindeer buck
(male) who possesses an unusual luminous red nose. Mocked and excluded by his
peers because of this trait, Rudolph proves himself one [Christmas
Eve](/wiki/Christmas_Eve "Christmas Eve") with poor visibility due to
inclement weather after [Santa Claus](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus") catches
sight of Rudolph's nose and asks Rudolph to lead his sleigh for the evening.
Rudolph agrees and is finally favored by his fellow reindeer for his heroism
and accomplishment.

## In media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: In media")]

### Theatrical cartoon short (1948)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Theatrical cartoon short
\(1948\)")]

Main article: [Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (1948
film)](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer_\(1948_film\) "Rudolph the Red-
Nosed Reindeer \(1948 film\)")

Rudolph made his first screen appearance in 1948, in a cartoon short produced
by [Max Fleischer](/wiki/Max_Fleischer "Max Fleischer") for the [Jam
Handy](/wiki/Jam_Handy "Jam Handy") Corporation that was more faithful to
May's original story than Marks' song, which had not yet been written.[13] It
was reissued in 1951 with the song added.[13]

### Song (1949)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Song \(1949\)")]

Main article: [Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (song)](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer_\(song\) "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer \(song\)")

May's brother-in-law, [Johnny Marks](/wiki/Johnny_Marks "Johnny Marks"),
adapted the story of Rudolph into a song. [Gene Autry](/wiki/Gene_Autry "Gene
Autry")'s recording of the song hit No. 1 on the
_[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard \(magazine\)")_ pop
singles chart the week of Christmas 1949. Autry's recording sold 2.5 million
copies the first year, eventually selling a total of 25 million, and it
remained the second best-selling record of all time until the 1980s.[14]

### Comic books (beginning in 1950)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Comic books \(beginning in
1950\)")]

[DC Comics](/wiki/DC_Comics "DC Comics"), then known as National Periodical
Publications, published a series of 13 [annuals](/wiki/Annual_publication
"Annual publication") titled _Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer_ from 1950 to
1962.[15][16] Rube Grossman drew most of the 1950s stories.[17]

In 1972, DC Comics published a 14th edition in an extra-large format.
Subsequently, they published six more in that format: _[Limited Collectors'
Edition](/wiki/Limited_Collectors%27_Edition "Limited Collectors' Edition")_
C-24, C-33, C-42, C-50[18] and _All-New Collectors ' Edition_ C-53, C-60.[19]

Additionally, one digest format edition was published as _The Best of DC_ #4
(March–April 1980).[20] The 1970s Rudolph stories were written and drawn by
[Sheldon Mayer](/wiki/Sheldon_Mayer "Sheldon Mayer").[21][22]

### Children's book (1958)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Children's book
\(1958\)")]

In 1958, [Little Golden Books](/wiki/Little_Golden_Books "Little Golden
Books") published an illustrated [storybook](/wiki/Children%27s_literature
"Children's literature"), adapted by Barbara Shook Hazen and illustrated by
[Richard Scarry](/wiki/Richard_Scarry "Richard Scarry"). The book, similar in
story to the [Max Fleischer](/wiki/Max_Fleischer "Max Fleischer") cartoon
short, is no longer in print,[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] but a
revised Little Golden Books version of the storybook was reissued in 1972.

### Stop-motion animation television special (1964) and sequels
(1976–79)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Stop-motion animation
television special \(1964\) and sequels \(1976–79\)")]

Main article: [Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (TV
special)](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer_\(TV_special\) "Rudolph the
Red-Nosed Reindeer \(TV special\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Hermey_the_elf_and_Rudolph.jpg/220px-
Hermey_the_elf_and_Rudolph.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hermey_the_elf_and_Rudolph.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hermey_the_elf_and_Rudolph.jpg "Enlarge")

Young Rudolph (right) and Hermey the Elf as seen in the 1964 TV special.

Perhaps the most well-known version of all the Rudolph adaptations is the
[Rankin/Bass Productions](/wiki/Rankin/Bass_Productions "Rankin/Bass
Productions") version of 1964.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Filmed
in Japan, with all sound recordings done in Toronto, Canada, the show
premièred on [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC"). As the producers of the special only had
the song as source material and did not have a copy of the original book, they
interpolated an original story around the central narrative of the song, one
that differed from the book. This re-telling chronicles Rudolph's social
rejection among his peers and his decision to run away from home. Rudolph is
accompanied by a similarly outcast elf named Hermey, who skipped elf practice
to become a dentist, along with a loud, boisterous, eager prospector named
Yukon Cornelius who was in search of wealth. Additional original characters
include Rudolph's love interest, Clarice; the antagonistic "Abominable Snow
Monster"; and, as narrator, the living Sam the Snowman, voiced by [Burl
Ives](/wiki/Burl_Ives "Burl Ives").

In the 1964 stop-motion movie, Rudolph is born to Donder the Reindeer and
Donder's wife. He is discovered by Santa to have a shiny, glowing red nose.
Donder, regardless of Rudolph's defect, trains him to be a normal reindeer
with skills such as gathering food and hiding from the "Abominable Snow
Monster", a giant, furry white beast. To hide Rudolph's nose, Donder puts dirt
on it to cover it with a black coating. This causes Rudolph to talk in a funny
accent, as told by the Rudolph's peers. A short time later, Rudolph joins his
peers at the Reindeer Games, where he meets Fireball, who is initially
friendly and has a shock of strawberry blond hair on his head, and Clarice, a
female spectator who takes a liking to Rudolph. Clarice's flirtation inspires
Rudolph to perform better than all of his peers at flying, but in his
excitement he knocks the black cover off his nose, revealing a red glow that
causes Fireball and the others to turn against him; this distraction, in turn,
prompts the coach (Comet) to ban Rudolph from the Reindeer Games. Clarice
remains loyal to him, only to be ordered by her father not to shame the family
by associating with "a red-nosed reindeer."

Rudolph soon runs into Hermey, an elf who was forced out of his job at the
North Pole's toy factory; Hermey showed a total lack of interest in the
toymaking and singing aspects of being an elf and instead wanted to pursue
dentistry. They come to the conclusion that they're both misfits and decide to
run away together. On their aimless journey, they run into Yukon Cornelius,
the self-described "greatest prospector of the North" who nevertheless seems
to never find any silver or gold, and attempt to stay away from the Bumble, a
huge [abominable snow monster](/wiki/Yeti "Yeti"). Their journey leads them to
the Island of Misfit Toys, where sentient but unorthodox toys go when they are
abandoned by their owners. King Moonracer, the winged lion that lords over the
Island, refuses to let them stay there permanently, instead telling the trio
to return home and tell Santa Claus of the toys' plight, in exchange for one
night's stay on the island. Rudolph refuses the offer and, fearing for his
friends' life, runs off alone.

A now older Rudolph, still unable to find a place in the world, returns home
to the North Pole, only to find that his family and Clarice had left to look
for him and are now about to be eaten by the Bumble. With the help of Hermey
and Yukon (who arrived separately), they lure the Bumble away and pacify him
by knocking him unconscious and allowing Hermey (with dental skills he has
acquired by reading books) to remove his sharp teeth. Everyone eventually
returns to Santa's workshop, where a dismayed Santa Claus breaks the bad news
that the weather is too bad to take the sleigh out and that Christmas would be
canceled. Santa changes his mind when he notices Rudolph's red nose and asks
Rudolph to lead the sleigh team, which he happily accepts.

After the story's initial broadcast, its closing credits were revised. Images
of wrapped presents being dropped from Santa's sleigh were replaced by a scene
in which Santa stops to pick up the Misfit Toys and delivers them to the homes
of children below, where they were found by children who loved them. The
changes were prompted by viewer feedback pleading for a happy ending for each
toy. The special now airs annually on CBS, rather than NBC, and is hailed as a
classic by many. The special's original assortment of characters have acquired
iconic status, and an uncertainty surrounding an error in the special's
copyright has allowed the special to be widely parodied and imitated in the
decades since its original airing.

The sequel _[Rudolph's Shiny New Year](/wiki/Rudolph%27s_Shiny_New_Year
"Rudolph's Shiny New Year")_ (premier air date December 10, 1976) continued
the reindeer's journeys, and the series was made into a trilogy with the 1979
feature-length film _[Christmas in
July](/wiki/Rudolph_and_Frosty%27s_Christmas_in_July "Rudolph and Frosty's
Christmas in July")_ , which integrated the _Rudolph_ universe into that of
Rankin/Bass's adaptation of _[Frosty the
Snowman](/wiki/Frosty_the_Snowman_\(TV_special\) "Frosty the Snowman \(TV
special\)")_.

### Animated feature-length films[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Animated feature-length
films")]

Main article: [Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The
Movie](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer:_The_Movie "Rudolph the Red-Nosed
Reindeer: The Movie")

_[Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Movie](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer:_The_Movie "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Movie")_ (1998)
is an animated feature film. It received only a limited theatrical release
before debuting on [home video](/wiki/Home_video "Home video"). Its inclusion
of a [villain](/wiki/Villain "Villain"), a love interest, a sidekick, and a
strong protector are more derivative of the Rankin/Bass adaptation of the
story than the original tale and song (the characters of Stormella, Zoey,
Arrow, Slyly, and Leonard parallel the Rankin/Bass characters of the Bumble,
Clarice, Fireball, Hermey, and Yukon, respectively). The movie amplifies the
early backstory of Rudolph's harassment by his schoolmates (primarily his
cousin Arrow) during his formative years.

Main article: [Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer and the Island of Misfit
Toys](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer_and_the_Island_of_Misfit_Toys
"Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer and the Island of Misfit Toys")

[GoodTimes Entertainment](/wiki/GoodTimes_Entertainment "GoodTimes
Entertainment"), the producers of _Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Movie_
, brought back most of the same production team for a [CGI
animated](/wiki/CGI_animated "CGI animated") sequel, _[Rudolph the Red-Nosed
Reindeer and the Island of Misfit Toys](/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer_and_the_Island_of_Misfit_Toys "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer
and the Island of Misfit Toys")_ (2001). Unlike the previous film, the sequel
featured the original characters from the Rankin/Bass special (as GoodTimes
soon learned that Rankin/Bass had made a copyright error that made the
characters unique to their special free to use).

### Other[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Other")]

A live-action version of Rudolph (complete with glowing nose) along with
Donder and Blitzen appears in the _[Doctor Who](/wiki/Doctor_Who "Doctor
Who")_ Christmas special, "[Last
Christmas](/wiki/Last_Christmas_\(Doctor_Who\) "Last Christmas \(Doctor
Who\)")" which was broadcast on [BBC One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One") on 25
December 2014.[23] In this special, Santa is able to park him like a car and
turn off his nose.

Nathaniel Dominy, an anthropology professor at [Dartmouth
College](/wiki/Dartmouth_College "Dartmouth College") (Robert L. May's alma
mater), published a scholarly paper on Rudolph's red nose in the [open
access](/wiki/Open_access "Open access") online journal _[Frontiers for Young
Minds](/wiki/Frontiers_Media#Frontiers_for_Young_Minds "Frontiers Media")_ in
2015. In the paper, Dominy noted that reindeer eyes can perceive shorter
wavelengths of light than humans, allowing them to see ultraviolet light;
ultraviolet light, however, is much more easily scattered in fog, which would
blind reindeer. Thus, Rudolph's red nose, emitting longer-wavelength red
light, would penetrate the fog more easily. A summary of Dominy's findings was
released in an _Associated Press_ article on December 22.[24]

### Film[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Film")]

  * In the [film remake of Dr. Seuss' _How the Grinch Stole Christmas_](/wiki/Dr._Seuss%27_How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas_\(2000_film\) "Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas \(2000 film\)") (2000), [The Grinch](/wiki/The_Grinch "The Grinch") disguises his dog, Max, as Rudolph for his plan to disguise himself as [Santa Claus](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus") and steal everything in each house in [Whoville](/wiki/Whoville "Whoville"), to stop [Christmas](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas") from coming. He also changes Rudolph's story saying, he hates Christmas and is gonna steal it. He then yells "Action!" through a [megaphone](/wiki/Megaphone "Megaphone"). But Max takes off the fake red nose the Grinch had put on him.
  * In the film _[Fred Claus](/wiki/Fred_Claus "Fred Claus")_ (2007), Rudolph is mentioned and briefly seen, although his red nose is not glowing. Fred ([Vince Vaughn](/wiki/Vince_Vaughn "Vince Vaughn")) is filling in for his injured brother [Nick](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus") ([Paul Giamatti](/wiki/Paul_Giamatti "Paul Giamatti")) delivering the toys on [Christmas Eve](/wiki/Christmas_Eve "Christmas Eve"). While _en route_ , he crashes the sleigh through a [billboard](/wiki/Billboard "Billboard") advertisement for [Pepsi Cola](/wiki/Pepsi_Cola "Pepsi Cola") featuring Santa Claus and tells Rudolph to "shake it off". There are quick edits of Fred flying through the night making his deliveries. Willie the elf says, "Fred, I have a bad feeling about this", followed by a shot of the full moon. The sleigh zips by and turns to go head on into the camera. Here, you can see Rudolph leading the pack. In slow motion, you can clearly count nine reindeer.

### Games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Games")]

  * Rudolph is mentioned in the video game _[Army of Two](/wiki/Army_of_Two "Army of Two")_ (2008) during a tutorial video about the use of the game's Aggro feature.
  * In _[Guild Wars Nightfall](/wiki/Guild_Wars_Nightfall "Guild Wars Nightfall")_ (2006), player characters are accompanied by a reindeer named Rudy whose nose begins to glow red when coming into range of presents that the player is tasked to find in a holiday themed quest.

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Music")]

  * Rudolph is mentioned in the [Beach Boys](/wiki/The_Beach_Boys "The Beach Boys")' song "[Little Saint Nick](/wiki/Little_Saint_Nick "Little Saint Nick")" (1963) in the following lyric: "Now haulin' through the snow at a frightening speed with a half a dozen deer with Rudy to lead."[25]
  * "[Run Rudolph Run](/wiki/Run_Rudolph_Run "Run Rudolph Run")" (1958) is a [Christmas song](/wiki/Christmas_song "Christmas song") popularized by [Chuck Berry](/wiki/Chuck_Berry "Chuck Berry") and written by [Johnny Marks](/wiki/Johnny_Marks "Johnny Marks") and Marvin Brodie and published by St. Nicholas Music (ASCAP). The song was released as a single on Chess Records (label no. 1714) and has since been covered by numerous other artists, sometimes under the title "Run, Run, Rudolph". The song is a 12-bar blues and has a clear musical parallel to Chuck Berry's popular and recognizable song, "[Johnny B. Goode](/wiki/Johnny_B._Goode "Johnny B. Goode")" (1958);[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] it is also melodically identical to Berry's "[Little Queenie](/wiki/Little_Queenie "Little Queenie")" (1959).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * In [Ray Stevens](/wiki/Ray_Stevens "Ray Stevens")' novelty song "Santa Claus Is Watching You" (1962), Rudolph is replaced on Santa's team by "Clyde the Camel", a character from Steven's earlier hit, "[Ahab the Arab](/wiki/Ahab_the_Arab "Ahab the Arab")". In the original version, aimed at children in a similar fashion to "[Santa Claus Is Coming to Town](/wiki/Santa_Claus_Is_Coming_to_Town "Santa Claus Is Coming to Town")", Rudolph was said to be recuperating from an injury sustained during "a [twist](/wiki/Twist_\(dance\) "Twist \(dance\)") contest"; a later version, warning a lover away from [infidelity](/wiki/Infidelity "Infidelity") because Santa is watching, has Rudolph on a "[stakeout](/wiki/Stakeout "Stakeout") at (the lover's) house".

### Television and webisodes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Television and
webisodes")]

  * In the _[Doctor Who](/wiki/Doctor_Who "Doctor Who")_ promotional mini-webisode, "[Songtaran Carols](/wiki/The_Snowmen#Prequels "The Snowmen")" (2012), the [Sontaran](/wiki/Sontaran "Sontaran") warrior-nurse-detective, Strax, stated: "Rudolph the red-nosed reindeer, had a very shiny nose. It proved to be a tactical disadvantage, because it enabled me to punch him in the dark."
  * Rudolph along with Donder and Blitzen appear in the _Doctor Who_ Christmas special, _[Last Christmas](/wiki/Last_Christmas_\(Doctor_Who\) "Last Christmas \(Doctor Who\)")_.
  * The anime and manga series [One Piece](/wiki/One_Piece "One Piece") has a main character called [Tony Tony Chopper](/wiki/Tony_Tony_Chopper "Tony Tony Chopper"), a shapeshifter born on Christmas Eve, who was often discriminated against because of his blue nose. However his background and story is otherwise very different.
  * [MadTV](/wiki/MadTV "MadTV") featured Rudolph in a parody of the 1964 Rankin-Bass special called _Raging Rudolph_. Rudolph is beaten up for his red nose, and decides to get revenge on Santa Claus with Hermie the Elf by hiring Yukon Cornelius (a hitman in the special) to kill and decapitate Santa. Rudolph then takes over the North Pole. A sequel to the skit, _The Reinfather_ , shows Rudolph exacting revenge for his hitman's death in a nod to _[The Godfather](/wiki/The_Godfather_\(film\) "The Godfather \(film\)")_.

## Relatives in different
adaptations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Relatives in different
adaptations")]

Main article: [Santa Claus's reindeer § Additional
reindeer](/wiki/Santa_Claus%27s_reindeer#Additional_reindeer "Santa Claus's
reindeer")

### Parents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Parents")]

  * Robert L. May's original book does not name Rudolph's parents.
  * The animated specials produced by both Rankin/Bass and GoodTimes Entertainment have given Rudolph different sets of parents: 
    * In Rankin/Bass's holiday special, he is [Donder](/wiki/Donder_the_reindeer#The_original_eight_reindeer "Donder the reindeer")'s son, and his mother is a tan doe who is called Mrs. Donder.
    * In GoodTimes' retelling, Rudolph's father is [Blitzen](/wiki/Blitzen_the_Reindeer "Blitzen the Reindeer"), and his mother is named Mitzi.

### Offspring[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Offspring")]

Three [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") animations carry on the legend by introducing
Rudolph's son, [Robbie the Reindeer](/wiki/Robbie_the_Reindeer "Robbie the
Reindeer"). However, Rudolph is never directly mentioned by name (references
are replaced by the first and second films' villain Blitzen interrupting with
the phrase, "Don't say that name!", or something similar, presumably for
[copyright](/wiki/Copyright "Copyright") reasons.)

### Siblings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Siblings")]

Rudolph is also given a younger brother, Rusty Reindeer, in the American
special, _[Holidaze: The Christmas That Almost Didn't
Happen](/wiki/Holidaze:_The_Christmas_That_Almost_Didn%27t_Happen "Holidaze:
The Christmas That Almost Didn't Happen")_ (2006). Unlike in the "Robbie the
Reindeer" cartoons, Rudolph's name is mentioned in the film.

Michael Fry and [T. Lewis](/wiki/T._Lewis "T. Lewis") have given Rudolph
another brother in a series of _[Over the Hedge](/wiki/Over_the_Hedge "Over
the Hedge")_ [comic strips](/wiki/Comic_strip "Comic strip"): an overweight,
emotionally damaged reindeer named Ralph, the Infra-Red nosed Reindeer, who is
referred to as Rudolph's older brother. Ralph's red nose is good for
defrosting Santa's sleigh and warming up toast and waffles; he enviously
complains about his brother Rudolph's publicity and his own anonymity.

### Aunts, uncles, and cousins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_the_Red-
Nosed_Reindeer&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Aunts, uncles, and
cousins")]

  * Rudolph has a cousin, Leroy, in [Joe Diffie](/wiki/Joe_Diffie "Joe Diffie")'s 1995 song, "[Leroy the Redneck Reindeer](/wiki/Leroy_the_Redneck_Reindeer "Leroy the Redneck Reindeer")" (1995), which tells the story of Leroy's joining the sleigh team to substitute for Rudolph, who was ill.
  * In GoodTimes' retelling, three of Santa's reindeer (Dasher, Comet, and Cupid) are his uncles, and Cupid's son Arrow is Rudolph's cousin and rival.
